_items.body: This should be more than plenty. If not, you should probably consider using a different component or splitting your content up.

_items.title: To infinity...

_items.title: Why use a flipper
_items.body: Whilst you can include graphics, this element is particularly useful for making text lists a bit more interesting.

title: Stacklist
_items: This component is useful for making boring text lists that little bit more interactive.
List items slide in from alternating sides.
There is no limit to the number of items you can have.
Although if you have too many it will be a bit boring.
At least now you get the gist of how this works.

_items.title: The Background Scroll Component
_items.body: This component is great for using when you have high quality HD images to work with.

_items.title: Single Component - Multiple Backgrounds
_items.body: Each item has its own background image, title and description.
Titles are optional so you can just display a paragraph of text if preferred.

_items.title: Feel more connected
_items.body: The image fades are determined by your scroll position rather than being a triggered animation, making the transition feel more connected with the learner's interaction.

_items.title: Completing the Component
_items.body: There is a timer on each item to make sure the learner cannot complete the component simply by scrolling to the bottom instantly.

_items.title: Make an Impact
_items.body: Get your learner's attention using high quality images with the Background Scroll component.

title: HTML - Default Template Basic
_items: If you do not specify a template then the component will use its supplied default.
There's lot that can be accomplished using the default template.
In its most basic form it will render an array of "_items" into individual elements with a class of .html-item which can then be styled as you choose.
Each item is also given a class of .nth-child-n according to its index.
So you can style each item independently.

title: HTML - Default Template Advanced
_items: You can also specify an object as one of the "_items" which will render each of its properties into a separate element with a class .html-item-{{property}}. This is useful for rendering multiple items each with different elements or sections.

_items.title: Item 1
_items.description: Using the _id of the component and the nth-child classes you can apply custom styling to each item and property.

_items.title: Item 2
_items.description: In this component for example, the title of each item is assigned a class of .html-item-title.

_items.title: Item 3
_items.description: And each description property is rendered into an element with a class of .html-item-description

_items.title: Item 4
_items.description: These items only have two properties, title and description, but there is no limit to the number you can have.
